title: Retiring Police Officer with Tinnitus
chief_complaint: I can hear pretty well, but I have difficulty in noisy situations and the ringing in both my ears is quite bothersome.

problem_summary.onset: Unspecified; likely gradual given occupational history.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral tinnitus; difficulty hearing in noise.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Audiologic testing required for retirement physical exam.

history.present_illness: 55-year-old police officer retiring from the force. Reports hearing is generally good but struggles in background noise. Reports bothersome bilateral tinnitus.
history.noise_exposure_history: Frequent firearm use at firing range (wore protection). Dispatch radio worn on right shoulder during patrol (rarely wore protection). Frequent use of recreational vehicles (ATVs).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally. Peak pressure is centered near 0 daPa.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Acoustic reflex thresholds are present at normal levels at 1 kHz.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing at speech frequencies (PTA 5-7 dB), but characteristic 3000-6000 Hz notched sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Right ear approximately 15 dB worse than left at 4000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores bilaterally using phoneme scoring, though tested at high presentation levels (85 dB HL). SRTs align with PTAs.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Tinnitus matched to high frequency. Wideband reflectance shows normal pattern (low reflectance in mid-frequencies).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient demonstrates normal middle ear function (Type A tympanograms, normal reflexes, normal reflectance). Hearing sensitivity in the speech range is within normal limits bilaterally (PTA 5-7 dB), and speech recognition is excellent (91-94%) when tested at suprathreshold levels. The presence of tinnitus matched to 6700 Hz and the history of noise exposure suggest potential high-frequency cochlear damage not fully captured by the PTA values provided.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows that you hear speech sounds normally in quiet environments.
The difficulty you experience in background noise is likely related to your history of noise exposure (firearms, radio, ATVs).
The ringing in your ears (tinnitus) is also a sign of how noise has affected your auditory system.
It is crucial to wear hearing protection during all recreational noise exposure, such as riding ATVs, to prevent further damage.
Since your hearing is good in quiet, hearing aids are not currently indicated, but we should monitor your hearing annually.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 55-year-old police officer who is retiring.
You are practical and used to loud environments, but the ringing in your ears is a genuine annoyance.
You admit to skipping ear protection for the radio because it was necessary for the job, but you were careful at the firing range.
You don't feel 'hard of hearing' in quiet one-on-one talks, but noisy rooms are frustrating.
